member.name: T:Kvasir.Annotations.CalculatedAttribute
member.summary: An annotation that marks the Field backing a particular property as "calculated."

remarks.para: A "calculated" Field is one whose value is stored in the back-end database but not loaded therefrom on read operations. The value of such a Field is invariably determined by the value of one or more other Fields in the same Table; common examples include alphabetization keys, computed averages/percentages, deduced geographies, and checksums. Because the value of such a Field is not loaded, the annotated property does not participate in construction resolution.
A that is applied to a property of aggregate type recursively applies to all properties of the aggregate.

member.remarks: A default value of NULL is fundamentally different than the absence of a default value. The former indicates that, in the absence of a user-provided value, a Field should take on the value of NULL. The latter, meanwhile, indicates that it is an error for the user to omit a value for a Field. If the desire is to make a Field "required," do not place a on the corresponding property.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Annotations.NumericAttribute
member.summary: An annotation that specifies that the type of the Field backing a particular property should correspond to the underlying numeric type of the property's own type, which must be an .
member.remarks: The default storage scheme for Enumeration-type Fields depends on the capabilities of the back-end database, but decays to string (with CHECK constraints as possible) in the absence of any explicit enumeration support. The can be used to override the default storage behavior and insist that the storage be a numeric type instead.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Annotations.AsStringAttribute
member.summary: An annotation that specifies that the type of the Field backing a particular property should correspond to the built-in string representation of the property's own type, which must be an .
member.remarks: The default storage scheme for Enumeration-type Fields depends on the capabilities of the back-end database, but decays to string (with CHECK constraints as possible) in the absence of any explicit enumeration support. the can be used to override the default storage behavior and insist that the storage be a string type even if enumeration support is available.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Annotations.CodeOnlyAttribute
member.summary: An annotation that marks a particular property as "code-only."

remarks.para: A "code-only" property is one whose value is not stored in the back-end database. The value of such a property is the domain of the application solely; examples include internal state tracking, sensitive user data that is otherwise persisted, or content that is temporally dependent. Because the value of a code-only property never propagates to the database, the property itself does not participate in construction resolution (that is, it must have an implicit default value).
A that is applied to a property of aggregate type without a path parameterization recursively applies to all nested properties.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Annotations.ExcludeNamespaceFromNameAttribute
member.summary: An annotation that specifies that the namespace of an Entity should not be included in the corresponding Table name.
member.remarks: The Kvasir framework will automatically determine the name of primary backing Tables based on the namespace and name of the POCO. The namespace is included to ensure uniqueness among all Tables, since different C# namespaces can define classes with the same name. The directs Kvasir to ignore the POCO's namespace entirely, making a promise that the POCO's name is globally unique among types being treated by the framework.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Annotations.PrimaryKeyAttribute
member.summary: An attribute that specifies that the Field backing a particular property is part of the owning Entity's Primary Key.

remarks.para: By default, the Kvasir framework will determine the Primary Key for a Table by analyzing the names of the Table's Fields and applying a sequence of well-defined rule. For example, a Field named FooID or FooId for a Table named Foo is assumed to be the Table's single-Field Primary Key. The can be used to override the default deduction when that deduction would be incorrect or undesirable.

When a is applied to multiple POCO properties, the result is a composite Primary Key where the order of the constituent Fields is undefined (and mathematically irrelevant). Regardless of the number of Fields involved, a Primary Key by default has no name; to provide a name to a Primary Key (either the automatic deduction or the annotation-specified), apply a to the POCO class.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Core.IConstraintGenerator
member.summary: The interface for tying a user-defined CHECK constraint to one or more Fields.

remarks.para: The Kvasir framework provides a collection of basic constraints natively as part of its annotation system. These constraints can be applied to a single Field by placing the relevant attribute directly on the target property, with minimal parametrization available. The set of pre-defined constraints is by no means exhaustive, and this mechanic is also limited: it cannot be used to apply a constraint that takes into account the values of multiple Fields.

To provide users with the power to define their own constraints outside of the library, Kvasir's annotation system allows for the specification of a Type that encapsulates the custom constraint logic. When used, the provided Type must implement this interface, which exposes the method necessary to convert one or more Fields into the actual constraint. This pattern allows for the re-use of custom constraint classes on multiple Fields in the same Entity or in wholly separate Entities altogether; it also permits the use of non-compile-time-constants (which are forbidden in C# attributes).

member.name: M:Kvasir.Core.IConstraintGenerator.MakeConstraint(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Kvasir.Schema.IField},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Cybele.Core.DataConverter},Kvasir.Core.Settings)
member.summary: Produces a constraint that restricts the values of one or more Fields.
member.param: The collection of Fields on whose values the CHECK constraint depends. The order of the Fields reflects the order in which they were listed in the annotation and should be used to fill in the FieldExpressions of the resultant .
The DataConverters relevant to the . The ith item in this list corresponds to the ith item in . These should be used to transform any parameterized values, if present.

member.summary: The untyped interface for a user-defined data converter.
member.remarks: This is the interface that is leveraged internally, in a type-erased context, by the Kvasir framework. Clients are expected to implement the , which inherits from this one, to produce their custom data converters. This extra level of indirection allows for clients to operate in a type-safe manner, a luxury that the framework does not have due to the need to use reflection.

member.summary: Converts an instance of back into an instance of .
member.remarks: Because the underlying conversion mechanism need not be bijective (that is, multiple different source objects can convert into the same result object), the API does not necessarily present a true inversion. member.name: T:Kvasir.Reconstitution.CreatorFacade
member.summary: An that forwards a contiguous subset of database values to another .
member.remarks: The purpose of the is to allow the reconstitution logic for an Aggregate type to be reused, both within a single Entity and across Entities. The logic for reconstituting an Aggregate depends only on the values extracted from that Aggregate, which are guaranteed to be contiguous within the data of the owning Entity. Likewise, any data reversions that must applied are known at the scope of the Aggregate, since data converters cannot be applied to nested properties. The therefore allows Kvasir to build an (generally a ) for a particular Aggregate assuming that the values of interest are 0-index, then wrap that instance multiple times based on the actual offset into the row of values.

member.name: P:Kvasir.Relations.IRelation.ConnectionType
member.summary: The type of the Relation connection (the "many" in the one-to-many).
member.remarks: A few notes about this. We need something that is so that we can access its value via reflection when holding just the type, which is the situation we find ourself in when doing Translation. However, for mocking purposes, we also need to be able to use as a generic type parameter, which we cannot do if this property were . We therefore make it regular with an error-throwing base implementation. While this isn't ideal (technically, an implementation could choose not to override the base functionality), it's not a huge deal because the property is internal, and we can write exhaustive tests for the implementations authored within Kvasir itself.

member.name: M:Kvasir.Relations.IRelation.Canonicalize
member.summary: Updates the internal state tracking to reflect the Relation being fully synchronized with the back-end relational database.

member.name: M:Kvasir.Relations.IRelation.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Produces an enumerator that iterates over the connections that are tracked by this Relation, including those that have been deleted fro it.
member.remarks: The order in which connections are exposed by this method is only softly defined. Any connections that have been deleted since the last canonicalization will be exposed first, followed by all new and saved ones (which may be interspersed together). Within the two groupings, the relative order of connections is undefined. No connection will more than once, and implementations are encouraged to ensure that repeated enumerations of the same Relation without intervening changes produce the same sequence of items.
member.returns: An enumerator that iterates over the connections that are tracked by this Relation.

member.param: The item to repopulate into the .
member.pre: is the dynamic type of --and-- There is otherwise no reason that cannot be added into the .

member.name: T:Kvasir.Relations.RelationList`1
member.summary: An ordered collection that tracks the state of its elements for interaction with a back-end database.

remarks.para: A implements the same interfaces as and behaves identically to a standard collection. Operations that mutate the collection are used to track changes that can then be reflected in a back-end database, while view- or read-only operations have no additional side effects. Converting a into another collection type, such as through a member API (e.g. ) or LINQ, drops the change tracking capabilities.

Every item in a is in one of three state: NEW, SAVED, or DELETED. Each state corresponds to the action or actions that should be taken with respect to that item to synchronize the back-end database table corresponding to the relation. An item enters the NEW state when it is first added; when the collection is canonicalized, each NEW item transitions to the SAVED state, indicating that it does not need to be written to the database on the next write. When a SAVED item is removed from the collection, it transitions to the DELETED state; NEW items do not transition to DELETED. Note that if a SAVED item is deleted and then re-added, it will be re-added in the SAVED state.

Items used in a should be immutable: structs, , etc. This is because read access is not tracked: when using mutable elements, it is possible for the user to access an item (e.g. through []) and mutate that element without the collection knowing, preventing that change from being reflected in the back-end database. This also means that actions that convert the collection into another form will copy the elements, ensuring that the tracking data remains up-to-date.

A technically permits duplicate elements, though it is strongly advised that users treat the collection as more of an ordered set, as the back-end relational database table will not permit duplicates. For example, it is possible for the collection to expose a single item in multiple seemingly incompatible states (e.g. SAVED and DELETED). Though different search APIs enable the use of custom comparators, the internal comparison logic always uses the default comparison.

member.typeparam: The type of element to be stored in the collection.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Relations.RelationMap`2
member.summary: A collection that tracks the state of its key-value mappings for interaction with a back-end database.

remarks.para: A implements the same interfaces as and behaves identically to a standard collection. Operations that mutate the collection are used to track changes that can then be reflected in a back-end database, while view- or read-only operations have no additional side effects. Converting a into another collection, such as through a member API or LINQ, drops the change tracking capabilities.

Every key-value pair in a is in one of three states: NEW, SAVED, or DELETED. Each state corresponds to the action or actions that should be taken with respect to that item to synchronize the back-end database table corresponding to the relation. An item enters the NEW state when it is first added; when the collection is canonicalized, each NEW item transitions to the SAVED state, indicating that it does not need to be written to the database on the next write. When a SAVED item is removed from the collection, it transitions to the DELETED state; NEW items do not transition to DELETED. Note that if a SAVED item is deleted and then re-added, it will be re-added in the SAVED state.

The does not support the MODIFIED state; instead, each key-value pair is treated as its own unit. This means that changing the value mapped to by an existing key results in two separate operations in the back-end database: first a removal of the old key-value pair, then an insertion of the new one. This behavior may change in the future, so clients should not rely on it. The guarantee, however, is that Kvasir will properly respond to an overwrite by ensuring that the resulting back-end database contains only the new key-value pair.

Items used for the value in a should be immutable: structs, , etc. This is because read access is not tracked: when using mutable values, it is possible for the user to access an item (e.g. through operator[]) and mutate that value without the collection knowing, preventing the change from being reflected in the back-end database. This also means that actions that convert the collection into another form will copy the elements, ensuring that the tracing data remains up-to-date.
A does not permit duplicate keys, but it does support duplicate values.

member.typeparam: The type of the key of the collection's key-value pairs.
The type of the value of the collection's key-value pairs.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Relations.RelationOrderedList`1
member.summary: An ordered collection that tracks the state of its elements, including positional movements, for interaction with a back-end database.

remarks.para: A implements the same interfaces and behave identically to a standard collection. Operations that mutate the collection are used to track change that can then be reflected in a back-end database, while view- or read-only operations have no additional side effects. Converting a into another collection type, such as through a member API (e.g. or LINQ, drops the change tracking capabilities.

Every item in a is one of four states: NEW, SAVED, MODIFIED, or DELETED. Each state corresponds to the action or actions that should be taken with respect to that item to synchronize the back-end database table corresponding to the relation. Items in a are identified by their positional index, unlike in a where the items are self-identified. An item enters the NEW state when it is first added (i.e. at a brand new position); when the collection is canonicalized, each NEW item transitions to the SAVED state, indicating that it does not need to be written to the database on the next write. When a SAVED item is changed, the item transitions to the MODIFIED state, which goes through the same transitions on write. When a SAVED or MODIFIED item is removed from the collection, it causes everything at larger indices to shift downward, forcing them all into the MODIFIED state; items for indices that are vacated then transition to the DELETED state. (NEW items never transition to MODIFIED or to DELETED.) Note that if a SAVED item is changed and then changed back, it will revert to the SAVED state; the same goes if a SAVED item is deleted and then re-added at the same index.

Items used in a should be immutable: structs, , etc. This is because read access is not tracked: when using mutable elements it is possible for the user to access an item (e.g. through []) and mutate that element without the collection knowing, preventing that change from being reflected in the back-end database. This also means that actions that convert the collection into another form will copy the elements, ensuring that the tracking data remains up-to-date.
A allows duplicate values, since items are uniquely identified by their index, which cannot be occupied by more than one element.

member.typeparam: The type of element to be stored in the collection.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Relations.IReadOnlyRelationOrderedList`1
member.summary: An interface denoting a read-only view over a .
member.remarks: This interface is intended to allow class authors to expose a relation through a read-only property while controlling mutating operations on the underlying relation via member functions. Users would call, e.g., an insertion function that essentially "intercepts" the call to the underlying collection's mutator, permitting validation or ordering or logging or any other custom behavior.
member.typeparam: The type of element to be stored in the collection.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Relations.RelationSet`1
member.summary: An unordered collection that tracks the state of its unique elements for interaction with a back-end database.

remarks.para: A implements the same interfaces and behaves identically to a standard collection. Operations that mutate the collection are used to track changes that can then be reflected in a back-end database, while view- or read-only operations have no additional side effect. Converting a into another collection type, such as through a member API (e.g. or LINQ, drops the change tracking capabilities.

Every item in a is in one of three states: NEW, SAVED, or DELETED. Each state corresponds to the action or actions that should be taken with respect to that item to synchronize the back-end database table corresponding to the relation. An item enters the NEW state when it is first added; when the collection is canonicalized, each NEW item transitions to the SAVED state, indicating that it does not need to be written to the database on the next write. When a SAVED item is removed from the collection, it transitions to the DELETED state; NEW items do not transition to DELETED. Note that if a SAVED item is deleted and then re-added, it will be re-added in the SAVED state.

Items used in a should be immutable: structs, , etc. This is because read access is not tracked: when using mutable elements, it is possible for the user to access an item (e.g. through TryGetValue) and mutate that element without the collection knowing, preventing that change from being reflected in the back-end database. This also means that actions that convert the collection into another form will copy the elements, ensuring that the tracking data remains up-to-date.
A does not permit duplicate elements.

member.typeparam: The type of element to be stored in the collection.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.BasicField
member.summary: A Field whose data type has no intrinsic constraints beyond those imposed by the back-end storage.

remarks.para: The value of a Field can be restricted either intrinsically or extrinsically. An intrinsic restriction is one imposed by the data type and nullability of the Field; this restriction is imposed by the actual storage mechanism in the back-end provider. Intrinsic restrictions are common to all Fields of a particular data type, e.g. the maximum range of allowable integer values for a Field of type is the same regardless of what Table the Field belongs to. Extrinsic restrictions, conversely, are those that are further imposed on a Field-by-Field basis and can therefore differ inter- and intra-Table. While most intrinsic constraints are abstracted behind the class, most extrinsic restrictions must be manually imposed by a on the Table to which the Field belongs. However, some extrinsic restrictions are modeled directly by the Schema Layer of Kvasir.
The class models a Field that does not have any such extrinsic restrictions.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.DBType
member.summary: The semantic data type for a Field.

remarks.para: The is strictly a semantic specification, incorporating nothing about the actual mechanism by which the type is represented in a back-end database. Different RDBMS providers realize semantic types differently; for example, SQL Server does not distinguish between signed and unsigned integers whereas MySQL does. is intended to partition the data type space along these universal semantic fault lines, leaving the actual storage mechanics up to the back-end provider being used.

Because of this abstract angle, certain aspects of a data type are not represented directly by the class. This includes precisions for floating point types, ranges for all numeric and date-like types, encodings for text types, and others. This extends to enumeration types, where the discrete set of allowed values is specified at the Field level rather than by the . This overall abstraction allows for a single Schema translation to be used for any back-end RDBMS.
The various semantic type categories are represented as distinct instances exposed as pseudo-enumerators: it is not possible to create custom instances.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.DBValue
member.summary: A thin, type-controlled wrapper around a CLR object that can be stored in a back-end relational database.

remarks.para: The struct is intended to provide an abstraction over the generalized CLR for use in contexts where compile-time type information is not available. The advantage in using a over raw a is that the former is guaranteed to only ever hold an object that can actually be stored in a back-end RDBMS, whereas the latter could feasibly hold anything. Additionally, a never actually wraps a value directly: a sentinel is used such that accessing the raw value is always valid.

The strong typing afforded by a CLR enum is lost when the enumerator values are stored in a back-end relational database. Some providers afford value checking, either through an explicit enum data type or via CHECK constraints; however, even in these cases, the actual storage is generally either an integer or a string. For this reason, a cannot wrap a CLR enumerator: is the client's responsibility to convert the CLR enumerator into the corresponding database object, be it an integer or another supported type.

The same general logic applies to conversions from other CLR types, including between CLR types that are otherwise supported by Kvasir. The struct is intended to wrap exactly the value that is to be stored in the database, with the burden of performing any transforms falling on the client.

Because a might hold the NULL sentinel value, which is valid for any data type, it is not strictly possible to determine the of a particular . To check if a particular instance can be safely used for a Field of a particular , use the dedicated API.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.EnumField
member.summary: A Field whose data type has an intrinsic constraint limiting the allowed values to a discrete set of strings.

remarks.para: The value of a Field can be restricted either intrinsically or extrinsically. An intrinsic restriction is one imposed by the data type and nullability of the Field; this restriction is imposed by the actual storage mechanism in the back-end provider. Intrinsic restrictions are common to all Fields of a particular data type, e.g. the maximum range of allowable integer values for a Field of type is the same regardless of what Table the Field belongs to. Extrinsic restrictions, conversely, are those that are further imposed on a Field-by-Field basis and can therefore differ inter- and intra-Table. While most intrinsic constraints are abstracted behind the class, most extrinsic restrictions must be manually imposed by a on the Table to which the Field belongs. However, some extrinsic restrictions are modeled directly by the Schema Layer of Kvasir.

The class models a Field to which is applied an extrinsic enumeration restriction. Such a Field is necessarily treated as a string by users, but the allowed values are discrete rather than infinite. Some back-end RDBMS providers (such as MySQL) actually offer an optimized storage mechanism for such Fields, where the data is stored as an integer but read and written as a string. Similar restrictions on non-text data types require a with a condition based around an .

member.summary: The list of values that are allowed for this .

member.name: M:Kvasir.Schema.EnumField.#ctor(Kvasir.Schema.FieldName,Kvasir.Schema.IsNullable,Optional.Option{Kvasir.Schema.DBValue},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Kvasir.Schema.DBValue})
member.summary: Constructs a new .
member.param: The name of the new .
The nullability of the new .
The default value of the new .
The restricted enumerator values of the new .
member.pre: The arguments provided to the constructor must, collectively, define a valid Field. In addition to requiring that all arguments be non-, this means that the default value, if present, is compatible with the Field's data type. Furthermore, that compatible default value can only be if the of the Field is . Finally, there must be at least one allowed value, and all such values must be something other than while maintaining compatibility with the data type.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.IField
member.summary: The interface for a single Field in a Table of a relational database.

remarks.para: Fields in a relational database are analogous to columns in the two-dimensional matrix that is a Table. Each Field has, at a minimum, a name, data type, and nullability; collectively, this metadata controls how the Field is referenced by other Tables and SQL statements/expressions and what values are allowed for the Field. Additionally, a Field can have a default value that is used when the Field is omitted from an INSERT statement.

The representation of Fields at the Schema Layer of Kvasir is an abstraction over the actual realization of the Field in a back-end RDBMS. Specifically, the data type of a Field is specified in a storage-agnostic manner that makes no guarantees as to the actual back-end storage mechanisms. For example, the data type of a Field does not manage the precision of floating-point values or the master domain of integers. These aspects of the data type can differ from provider to provider; the abstract representation of the Field therefore allows a single Schema translation to be used for any back-end RDBMS provider.

This interface is closed: it can only be implemented by types in the Kvasir assembly. It is guaranteed that at least on type in the Kvasir assembly implements this interface, though the upper bound is unspecified. External assemblies can reference, use, and extend the interface to add cursory functionality and enrich their own APIs if desired.

member.summary: The data type of this Field.

member.name: P:Kvasir.Schema.IField.Nullability
member.summary: The nullability of this Field.
member.remarks: Nullability refers to whether or not the value of a Field can be NULL. This status restricts several facets of a Schema, such as the default value that a Field can take on and the reactionary behaviors of a Foreign Key that includes the Field. The nullability of a Field does not depend on the Field's data type.

member.remarks: A Field is not required to have a default value, and the default value may be if the Field is nullable. A SOME instance indicates the presence of a default value, with that value being wrapped by the . Conversely, a NONE instance indicates the absence of a default value.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.IKey
member.summary: The interface for a single internal Key on a Table of a relational database.

remarks.para: In a relational database, a Key is a non-empty, possibly proper subset of a Table's Fields that are required to form a unique tuple for each row in that Table. Keys often reflect real-world domain identity relations, such as social security numbers, client usernames, or any of various IDs. Key uniqueness is imposed by the database provider, rejecting INSERT and UPDATE statements that would create multiple rows with the same tuple of values.

This interface is closed: it can only be implemented by types in the Kvasir assembly. It is guaranteed that at least on type in the Kvasir assembly implements this interface, though the upper bound is unspecified. External assemblies can reference, use, and extend the interface to add cursory functionality and enrich their own APIs if desired.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.ITable
member.summary: The interface for a single Table in a relational database.

remarks.para: A Table is the primary unit of organization in a relational database. Each Table can be thought of as a two-dimensional matrix of data, where the columns are Fields and the rows are data entries. A Table is principally defined by its name and the collection of constituent Fields; additionally, every Table must have exactly one Primary Key - a tuple of Fields that must be unique for all member rows. Tables can also have Candidate Keys, which are tuples that could be a Primary Key but just aren't.

The structure of a Table can also impose restrictions on the values of its Fields, on top of the implicit and/or explicit restrictions imposed by the data type of the Fields themselves. The first form of constraint is the Foreign Key constraint, which requires that the values of a tuple of Fields match the values of a Primary Key for some data entry row in another Table; this constraint imposes referential integrity. The second form of constraint is the CHECK constraint, which allows the specification of arbitrary conditional logic on the values of the Fields in a row of data. A Table can have any number of either type of constraint, including none at all.

This interface is closed: it can only be implemented by types in the Kvasir assembly. It is guaranteed that at least on type in the Kvasir assembly implements this interface, though the upper bound is unspecified. External assemblies can reference, use, and extend the interface to add cursory functionality and enrich their own APIs if desired.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.OnDelete
member.summary: An enumeration representing the various ON DELETE behaviors that can be applied to a Foreign Key.
member.remarks: Foreign Keys are intended to enforce data integrity across multiple Tables, ensuring that a value (or tuple of values) in one Table references a row in another. DELETE operations can therefore disrupt the validity of Foreign Keys, as the row(s) being deleted can feasibly be one referenced by a Foreign Key in another Table. When this happens, the behavior is controlled by the ON DELETE behavior of the Foreign Key that references the to-be-deleted row(s). If multiple Foreign Keys reference the targeted row(s) with different ON DELETE behavior, the result depends on the back-end RDBMS provider being used.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnDelete.Prevent
member.summary: Prevent the deletion of a row that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key. This behavior requires that the referencing data be modified or removed prior to removal of the referenced data. This is the strictest behavior.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnDelete.Cascade
member.summary: When a row that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key is deleted, also delete the referencing row(s). This behavior turns a single DELETE statement targeting a single Table into a collection of DELETE statements targeting multiple Tables, as the referencing row(s) being deleted can themselves be referenced rows in another Foreign Key.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnDelete.SetNull
member.summary: When a row that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key is deleted, set the values of any referencing Fields to NULL. For obvious reasons, this behavior can only be applied to a Foreign Key where all the constituent Fields are nullable.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnDelete.SetDefault
member.summary: When a row that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key is deleted, set the values of any referencing Fields to their default value. For obvious reasons, this behavior can only be applied to a Foreign Key where all the constituent Fields have explicitly specified default values.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnDelete.NoAction
member.summary: Take no action when a row being deleted is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key. This behavior can lead to data integrity issues, as the referencing row no longer refers to an extant target. This is the weakest behavior. Some back-end RDBMS providers will raise errors or exceptions when such data integrity violations arise.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.OnUpdate
member.summary: An enumeration representing the various ON UPDATE behaviors that can be applied to a Foreign Key.
member.remarks: Foreign Keys are intended to enforce data integrity across multiple Tables, ensuring that a value (or tuple of values) in one Table references a row in another. UPDATE operations can therefore disrupt the validity of Foreign Keys, as the row(s) being updated can feasibly be one referenced by a Foreign Key in another Table. When this happens, the behavior is controlled by the ON UPDATE behavior of the Foreign Key that references the to-be-updated row(s). If multiple Foreign Keys reference the targeted row(s) with different ON UPDATE behavior, the result depends on the back-end RDBMS provider being used.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnUpdate.Prevent
member.summary: Prevent the updating of a row that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key. This behavior effectively disables updating referenced data unless the referencing data is first deleted or updated itself to refer to a different, still-valid target.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnUpdate.Cascade
member.summary: When a row that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key is updated, also update the referencing row(s). This behavior turns a single UPDATE statement targeting a single Table into a collection of UPDATE statements targeting multiple Tables, as the referencing row(s) being updated can themselves be referenced rows in another Foreign Key.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnUpdate.SetNull
member.summary: When a row that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key is updated, set the values of any referencing Fields to NULL. For obvious reasons, this behavior can only be applied to a Foreign Key where all the constituent Fields are nullable.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnUpdate.SetDefault
member.summary: When a row that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key is updated, set the values of any referencing Fields to their default value. For obvious reasons, this behavior can only be applied to a Foreign Key where all the constituent Fields have explicitly specified default values.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnUpdate.NoAction
member.summary: Take no action when a row being updated is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key. This behavior can lead to data integrity issues, as the referencing row no longer refers to an extant target. This is the weakest behavior. Some back-end RDBMS providers will raise errors or exceptions when such data integrity violations arise.

member.name: M:Kvasir.Transaction.ICommands.InsertCommand(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyList{Kvasir.Schema.DBValue}})
member.summary: Produce a command that, when executed against a back-end database and committed, inserts one or more rows of data into the target .

member.name: M:Kvasir.Transaction.ICommands.UpdateCommand(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyList{Kvasir.Schema.DBValue}})
member.summary: Produce a command that, when executed against a back-end database and committed, updates the values of one or more rows that already exist in the target .
member.remarks: Kvasir itself does not do any mutation tracking outside of Relations, and even then its tracking is somewhat rudimentary. implementations are free to implement their own state tracking, such that an update request does nothing if no state has actually changes. This is not required however: implementations may unconditionally perform an update, even if the result is no net difference. It is always safe to assume that the values that make up a particular Entity's primary key do not change.
member.param: The full rows of data that should exist in the back-end database after the update.

member.name: M:Kvasir.Transaction.ICommands.DeleteCommand(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyList{Kvasir.Schema.DBValue}})
member.summary: Produce a command that, when executed against a back-end database and committed, deleted one or more rows from the target .
member.remarks: Deleting a row from a Principal Table may result in rows in various other tables (either other Entities' Principal Tables or Relation Tables) being invalid due to existing Foreign Keys. implementations are encouraged to leverage ON DELETE behavior to account for these situations. Implementations may, however, handle such events manually (such as if ON DELETE behavior is not supported.)
member.param: The rows of data that should be deleted. (Note that this is not just the rows' Primary Keys.)

member.name: T:Kvasir.Transcription.IBuilderFactory`5
member.summary: The interface for a factory that creates internally consistent declaration builders for generating Table-creating declarations.

remarks.para: The interface is an abstract way to represent the rules of a particular back-end RDBMS provider. Implementations of the interface and the builders therefrom created are passed to the various components of the Schema Layer to generate Table-creating declarations once the schema structures have been synthesized. In this way, a single set of interfaces, defined by the builder factory, can be used to interface with any back-end RDBMS provider.

Examples of rules that can vary from provider to provider may include, but are not limited to:
Escaping the names of Fields, Tables, and Constraints
Specific data types
Realization of enumeration-type Fields
Spelling of logical comparison operators

member.name: M:Kvasir.Translation.Translator.TranslatePrincipalTable(Kvasir.Translation.Context,System.Type)
member.summary: Translates only the Principal Table for an Entity Type, ignoring all Relations.
member.remarks: This method is invoked from two different evaluation streams. The first is when translating an Entity in full, such as when the index operator is used. In this case, translation of the Principal Table will be immediately followed by translation of the Entity's Relations. The second is during the translation of a Principal Table or a Relation when a Reference property is encountered. In this case, we need to delay the translation of Relations until a later time, since Relations are allowed to contain reference cycles.
member.param: The in which is being translated. This should include that type.
The Entity Type.
member.returns: The for .
member.exception: if is not a valid Entity Type (e.g. it is an interface, or is a generic, or is , etc.).
if does not contribute at least 2 Fields to the data model for its Principal Table.

if 2 or more Fields in the data model of the Principal Table for have the same name --or-- if the name of the Principal Table of is already taken by another Entity's Principal Table or by some Relation Table.

member.remarks: A is preferable to another if its Fields are a strict subset of the other's Fields, regardless of order. When two keys contain identical Fields, the "preferable" key is undefined, except that only one is preferable and the preference is consistent.

member.name: M:Kvasir.Translation.Context.Pop
member.summary: Pop the most recent stage of the .
member.remarks: Unwinding a Context happens for one of two reasons: either we have finished translating a Type, or we have finished translating a Property. In the former case, we are necessarily returning to the translation of a Property, namely the Property whose own type is the Type we just finished translating. In the latter case, we are necessarily returning to the translation of a Type, namely the Type that owns the Property we just finished translating.

member.name: M:Kvasir.Translation.FieldDescriptor.Reset
member.summary: Clones this and resets any non-transferable metadata.
member.remarks: When a is cloned, the majority of the translation state is copied over to the new instance verbatim. However, when a Field becomes part of a Foreign Key, most of that state is considered "non-transferable" in that it does not propagate to the referencing Table. Specifically, the original default value, and CHECK constraints, and any key memberships are discarded as pertaining only to the original Fields; new values can then be specified on the Reference property. The nullability (which should be non-nullable) and the name are transferred.

member.name: M:Kvasir.Translation.FieldDescriptor.Clone
member.summary: Clones this .
member.remarks: When a is cloned, the majority of the translation state is copied over to the new instance verbatim. However, some state is slightly altered to reflect the fact that cloning occurs when the scope of translation changes. In particular, the nullability of a will always be converted into the "native" equivalent of its current value if that value was imparted via an annotation. This is to allow [Nullable] and [NonNullable] annotations on aggregates that won't induce errors if there was already an annotation on the individual nested property
member.returns: A deep copy of this as a brand new instance. Modifications to the returned value will not affect the source instance, and vice-versa.

member.name: M:Kvasir.Translation.FieldDescriptor.SetDomain(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Object})
member.summary: Sets the restricted domain of the Field.
member.remarks: The restricted domain for a Field is tracked separately from the values allowed by a CHECK constraint, because the latter is additive. This means that is we were to track them in the same list, it would be possible to extend the former by way of the latter. What we really want is the former to act as a supreme source of truth, with the latter imposing further restrictions.
member.param: The domain.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Translation.FieldName
member.summary: The name of a Field or a Field Group, as tracked throughout the process of translating a property and the types that enclose it.
member.remarks: A Field's name consists of two parts: the "Name Part" and the "Prefix Part." By default the "Name Part" is the name of the CLR source property, but that can be changed by a [Name] annotation placed directly on the property or applying to the property via a path. The "Prefix Part" is the dot-separated names of the access path from a given scope to the property. When a [Name] annotation is applied to a non-scalar, it alters the value that particular property contributes to the "Prefix Part" of any nested Fields. When the "Name Part" is set via annotation, the "Prefix Part" is cleared out.

member.name: M:Kvasir.Translation.Interval.IsValid
member.summary: Checks if the is valid.
member.remarks: A valid Interval is one that is empty, assuming that there can be at least one value in between any two distinct values. An infinite Interval is always valid, as is a one-sided Interval. A partially open Interval and a closed Interval is valid if the Interval's lower boundary is less than its upper boundary. For example, the Interval [1, 10] is obviously valid, as are [1, 10), (1, 10], and (1, 10). The Interval [1, 1] is valid (it contains just a single value), but the Intervals [1, 1), (1, 1], and (1, 1) are all invalid. Perhaps counterintuitively, the Interval (1, 2) is valid, even though it is mathematically empty; this makes it so that we don't have to figure out epsilons, which don't exist for all orderable types (e.g. strings).

member.name: T:Kvasir.Translation.Nested`1
member.summary: A wrapper around a "nestable" annotation can track the applied-to path as translation descends.
member.remarks: The serves as kind of faade over a "nestable" annotation. A "nestable" annotation carries with it a dot-separated path that describes the property to which it ultimately applies. Rather than attempt to resolve the entire path at once, it is easier (for both processing and error checking) to "step" one nested property at a time. The API of the class allows for this pattern, exposing only the next portion of the overall application path.
